mn26:67.3: Because it’s out of the hunter’s range.
mn26:67.4: In the same way, a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn26:67.5: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see.
mn26:68.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of samādhi, with internal clarity and confidence, and oneness of mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn26:68.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
mn26:69.1: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss’.
mn26:69.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
mn26:70.1: Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
mn26:70.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
mn26:71.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.
mn26:71.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
mn26:72.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
mn26:72.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
mn26:73.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
mn26:73.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
mn26:74.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
mn26:74.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
mn26:75.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.
mn26:75.2: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see.
mn26:75.3: They’ve crossed over clinging to the world. And they walk, stand, sit, and lie down in confidence.
mn26:75.5: Because they’re out of the Wicked One’s range.”
mn26:76.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn26:76.2: Uplifted, the mendicants approved of what the Buddha said.
